âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's on the easier side of hard, but is tricky enough to require some optimisation.

At first I thought it needed a lot of optimisation, but I soon realised that just some reasonable improvements would be enough to pass.

Fun puzzle.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: puzzle is simple at first glance but turns out to be much trickier, which makes the Hard difficulty well deserved.

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: The problem is indeed more difficult than it intuitively seems, and unfortunately, I peeked at the solution before coming up with my own for large n, which makes it a worthy candidate for the "hard" category.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: yeah... this puzzle  is hardest than The most beautiful puzzle.... the description of the problem is good, after solve it i saw your solution and i was surprised not to see a log function there.

Hello!

I'm curious about your contribution, which seems really interesting.

However, I feel like it is hard to understand it at first reading, especially about the "sum of the sums" stuff.
Maybe you can split that second sentence in two or three?

Something like:
- "Determine the number of integers [...] thath have at least one beautiful base"
- "Compute the sum of all of such beautiful bases for those integers. They are counted with their multiplicity."

I think another stuff you can hide to improve our understanding would be a detailed example.
Something like:
"For instance, there are 3 integers which are less than or equal to 10 that have at least one beautiful base:
- 4, admitting only 2 for beautiful base
- 8, admitting only 2 for beautiful base
- 9, admitting only 3 for beautiful base

The sum of all those beautiful bases is 2 * 2 + 3 = 7, so your program should output '3 7'"
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

Hello, I'm glad to know that my contribution interests you. You have perfectly understood the problem statement. What I'm struggling to express clearly is that we need to compute:
sum (sumOfAllBeautifulBases(i) for i in range(n) if hasBeautifulBase(i))

where we assume that sumOfAllBeautifulBases is a function that takes an integer i as a parameter and returns the sum of all the beautiful bases of i, and hasBeautifulBase is a function that takes an integer i as a parameter and returns True if this integer has at least one beautiful base, otherwise False.

Hello, I'm glad to know that you appreciated this puzzle at its true value. Indeed, it is more difficult than The Most Beautiful Base puzzle because it requires performing calculations over a large range of values, which likely needs to be reduced to avoid a timeout.

=== SPOIL ===






My solution uses a sieve-like approach that allows me to reduce the search space by a factor of 1/2, by iterating through all potential beautiful bases (from 2 to âˆšn). For each beautiful base, I compute all of its powers that are less than or equal to n, add them to a set to avoid duplicates, and increment the final sum by the base multiplied by the number of its powers that are â‰¤ n. This gives me an execution time of O(âˆšn * log n).

I'm curious to know how you approached the problem on your side.

Hi sic1,
Do you think you can re-approve my contribution so that it is finally accepted ?

well... i don't know much about execution time.... i checked how many iterations you do The ultimate challenge test in your code... and mine did only 14 iterations more than your code solution... my code:

(Code Erased)

NOTE: i will keep my code just few hours because i'm little careful of sharing it in this section
Edit: code erased

Ohhh, congratulations! Your solution is really clever and compact. If youâ€™ll allow me a few suggestions: replacing log10(n) / log10(2) with log2(n) would improve the readability of your code. Also, the min(n**.5, n**(1/qi)) in the second loop is unnecessarily defensive, since qi >= 2 implies 1/qi <= 1/2, which means n**(1/qi) <= n**.5. The condition if bi ** qi <= n is also mostly unnecessary. By using floor instead of round, you ensure that all bi^qi values are â‰¤ n and you also avoid some unnecessary iterations that you have leftover. ;-)

Thanks for your compliments.... and you right... the this inequation n**(1/qi) <= n**.5 implies n**(1/qi) is enough... i changed round by floor and not good results... in test 3 there was a problem with decimal fixed-point... the idea is good, but apply it in python isn't. Good puzzle again!
Thanks and it's a shame it didn't work.

Hi ManuelJ, 
Do you think you can re-approve my contribution so that it is finally accepted ?

Yes, I understand...
Perhaps using another example instead of 10, with a number admitting several bases like
32 (with 2 and 4 as beautiful bases)?

Actually, 32 cannot have 4 as a beautiful base because it is not a power of 4, but it does work with 16. I also updated the problem statement by adding an example (as you suggested) that illustrates how to compute the sum of the sums of the beautiful bases for all integers up to 16 that have at least one beautiful base.

Oops! ğŸ˜…
Wrong computation. I started with 64, and then try to get lower numbers.

Yeah, I think your example makes it easier to understand!

It looks nice.
